journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Development and simulation evaluation of a magnetorheological elastomer isolator for seat vibration control

article-meta.aff: 1School of Mechanical, Materials and Mechatronic Engineering, University of Wollongong, Wollongong, New South Wales, Australia
2Defence & Aerospace, G H Varley Pty Limited, TOMAGO, New South Wales, Australia
3School of Electrical, Computer and Telecommunications Engineering, University of Wollongong, New South Wales, Australia

author-notes.corresp: Weihua Li, School of Mechanical, Materials and Mechatronic Engineering, University of Wollongong, Wollongong, NSW 2522, Australia. Email: weihuali@uow.edu.au

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue on 12th International Conference on Electrorheological Fluids and Magnetorheological Suspensions - Part 2

abstract.p: Driver fatigue is one of the leading factors contributing to road crashes. Environmental stress, such as unwanted seat vibration, is a key contributor to fatigue. This article presents the design and development of a magnetorheological elastomer isolator for a seat suspension system. By altering the magnetorheological elastomer isolator’s stiffness through a controllable magnetic field and selecting suitable control strategy, the system’s natural frequency can be changed to avoid resonance, which consequently reduce the vehicle’s vibration energy input to seat, and thus suppress the seat’s response. Experimental results show that the developed magnetorheological elastomer isolator is able to reduce vibration more when compared with the passive isolation system, indicating the significant potential of its application in vehicle seat vibration control.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Fatigue is one of the leading factors contributing to road crashes. Driver’s fatigue as well as health and safety is significantly influenced by the seat vibration (Paddan and Griffin, 2002). In particular, the vibration transferring from the seat to the human body is a major source of discomfort for the driver. Generally, the seat vibration energy is concentrated at a low-frequency range of less than 10 Hz, which is generally considered as a sensitive range by human body. Such low frequencies can induce a kind of sea, air, or traffic sickness. Other problems include dizziness, balance disorder, and blindness (Choi and Han, 2007; Tong and Amirouche, 1998). For example, in a commercial vehicle, even though the driver’s body is not affected by the vibration of instruments, these sources of vibration can stretch the nerves and lead to serious fatigue. In a further stage, they can cause nausea and an uncomfortable feeling.

In general, there are three approaches to minimize unwanted vibrations in the structure of the driver’s seat of an automobile, that is, passive, active, and semi-active vibration control. The passive suspension system featuring conventional oil or gas damper provides design simplicity and cost effectiveness; however, the performance is limited because of uncontrollable damping force (Yu et al., 2009). The active control suspension requires high power consumption, many sensors, actuators, and sophisticated control logics, which often involve cost-effective and fail-safe issues (Yu et al., 2009). Recently, the semi-active suspension system has attracted considerable interest as it can offer a desirable performance without requiring large power consumption and expensive hardware (Rakheja et al., 1994; Tong et al., 1999).

For the last decade, a very attractive semi-active suspension system featuring electrorheological (ER) fluid and magnetorheological (MR) fluid (MRF) has been proposed by many investigators (Choi et al., 1998; Choi and Han, 2003; Choi and Wereley, 2002; McManus et al., 2002; Wereley and Pang, 1997). For example, a semi-active seat suspension system featuring ER fluids has been investigated for vibration isolation with various approaches (Choi et al., 1998; Wereley and Pang, 1997). The Lord Corporation presented a Seat Suspension for truck drivers. This proven solution integrates the MR technology as a component in the suspension system, such as the Motion Master™ Ride Management System, which was designed specifically for a Class 8 truck and off-highway machinery seating application (http://www.lord.com/products-and-solutions/magneto-rheological-(mr)/seat-suspension.xml)

This type of semi-active seat suspension has several advantages such as fast response time, continuously controllable damping force, and low energy consumption compared with the active seat suspension system.

However, these systems are only effective for a narrow frequency range, outside which the seat suspension will not be effective. This is because the ER fluid or the MRF has only controllable-damping capability (Li et al., 1999, 2000). The limitation is expected to be overcome by MR elastomers (MREs), which are an important branch of MR materials (Chen et al., 2007; Ginder et al., 2002; Li et al., 2010). Structurally, MREs can be thought of as solid analogues of MRFs. Such materials are composed of magnetized particles, for example, iron, dispersed in a polymer medium. Typically, magnetic fields are applied to the polymer composite during cross-linking such that particle-chain (columnar)-like structures form and become locked in place upon final cure. The formation of columnar particle structures within elastomers corresponds to a low dipolar energy state. Shearing of the cured composite in the presence of the magnetic field causes particle displacement from this low-energy state, thereby, requiring additional work. In principle, this required additional work rises monotonically with applied field, thus resulting in a field-dependent shear modulus.

Although MRFs and MREs have similar field response properties, there are some distinct differences in the way in which these two classes of materials are typically intended to operate. The most noteworthy is that MREs operate within the pre-yield regime (Chen et al., 2007; Li et al., 2010) while MRFs typically operate in a post-yield continuous shear or flow regime (Li et al., 2002, 2003). In addition, the “strength” of MRFs is characterized by yield stress while MREs are characterized by field-dependent modulus. With regard to application, MRE devices are used to adjust the natural frequency of a structure, which is dominated by the equivalent stiffness (Deng et al., 2006; Kim et al., 2011; Zhang and Li, 2009); while MRF devices provide a damping function, which is the process of dissipating energy (Li et al., 2000; Wang and Gordaninejad, 2007; Yao et al., 2002).

Different from controllable-damping devices, a device having controllable modulus material can provide elastic rebound force, which is in direct proportion to amplitude and stiffness. It is more suitable to control a low-frequency and high-amplitude vibration, just like car seat vibration. A novel suspension system based on MRE isolator is expected to provide promising applications. To our best knowledge, there is no similar research reported in literature. Therefore, the main contribution of this article is to present a stiffness controllable isolator.

This research consists of the following major tasks: (1) fabrication and characterization of MRE materials; (2) design, testing modeling of the MRE isolator, and evaluation of its controllable performance based on the nonresonance control algorithms; and (3) based on the displacement at seat frame and driver’s head, evaluation of vibration control effect of the isolator under chirp, bump, and random road conditions.

sec.title: Fabrication of MREs
sec.p: The room temperature vulcanizing (RTV) silicon rubber (H.B. Fuller Company, Germany) and silicone oil were chosen as matrix. The volume fraction ratio of silicone oil and silicone rubber in the matrix is 1:1. The average diameter of carbonyl iron particle is about 5 μm (BASF Company, Germany). The carbonyl iron particles were immersed in the silicone oil, then they were mixed with RTV silicone rubber. The mixture was put into a vacuum case to remove the air bubbles inside it, and then the mixture was poured into a mold. After being cured for about 24 h at room temperature under a constant magnetic flux density of 1 T (electromagnetism system, Peking EXCEEDLAN Inc., China), MRE samples were prepared. The volume fraction of iron powder is 30%.

sec.title: Characterization of MRE properties
sec.p: The MR effect was evaluated by measuring the dynamic shear modulus with and without an applied magnetic field using a Physica MRD 180 magnetorheological device (Anton Paar Companies, Germany), equipped with an electromagnet kit. The rubber segments were approximately φ 20 × 1 mm, and they were sandwiched between a rotary disk and a base.

The relationship between shear stress and shear strain, under various magnetic field strengths of MREs, is shown in Figure 1. The results show that such materials have controllable mechanical properties. The increase of the stress–strain loop area with magnetic field demonstrates that the damping capacity of MREs is a function of applied magnetic field, which is similar to MRFs. However, MREs distinguish themselves from MRFs in that their stiffness also increases steadily with magnetic field, as reflected by the slope of long-axis elliptic of stress–strain loop changes with magnetic field. According to the hysteresis loop, the modulus of the sample increases from 0.3 to 1.1 MPa. The increase is over three times under a 500 mT magnetic field, which means the device based on this material can hopefully have three times stiffness increase. These results demonstrate that MREs could be used as a novel variable stiffness device for tuned vibration control. The damping effect of MREs also shows an increasing trend with magnetic field, as the area of the stress–strain loops increases with the field. This implied that MREs can work as variable stiffness and damping materials. However, the field-dependent stiffness plays a relatively obvious role in the development of MRE devices, which will be demonstrated in the following study. A comprehensibly experimental study of MRE effect under various working conditions was reported in our previous work (Li et al., 2010; Popp et al., 2010).

caption.p: Stress–strain relationship of magnetorheological elastomers (MREs) at various magnetic fields.

sec.title: Design the MRE isolator
sec.p: The schematic of the proposed MRE seat isolator is shown in Figure 2. It is composed of core and base, coil, nonmagnetic rings, and MRE. The coils, core, and base form the electromagnet, which is used to generate varying magnetic fields. The nonmagnetic rings restrict the magnetic line to cross the MREs and come into being a magnetic circuit.

caption.p: Schematic of the magnetorheological elastomer (MRE) seat isolator.

sec.p: In this design, MRE functions as a variable spring. The current intensity in the coils can be controlled by electrical power to adjust the magnetic field intensity. As such, the modulus of MREs can be controlled in real time, that is, the stiffness of the spring can be adjusted to fit the special need.

sec.title: Performance testing and mathematical modeling
sec.p: A vibration testing system was constructed to characterize the MRE device, as shown in Figure 3. The device’s base is fixed on a vibration exciter. The device is forced to vibrate by the exciter (Type: JZK-5, Sinocera Piezotronics, Inc., China), which is driven by a fluctuating source from a power amplifier (YE5871-100W) whose signal is provided by the Data Acquisition (DAQ) board (Type: LabVIEW PCI-6221, National Instruments Corporation. USA) and computer. Force sensor (Type: CL-YD-302, Sinocera Piezotronics, Inc., China) monitors the force generated by exciter. The displacement sensor (ILD1700-10, BesTech Australia Pty Ltd) measures the displacement of the compressed surface of the air spring. The signals from force sensor and displacement sensor are amplified by a charge amplifier (YE5851) and processed and transferred by DAQ to the computer. A G & W Laboratories, Inc., direct current (DC) power supply (Type: GPR-3030D, Tecpel Co., Ltd. Taiwan) can adjust the input current on the MR valve in order to control the magnetic field intensity of the isolator and change its dynamic performance.

caption.p: Dynamic testing the magnetorheological elastomer (MRE) isolator.

sec.p: By applying harmonic inputs (5 Hz in this experiment) with different coil currents as well as magnetic fields, the response forces can be recorded. Thus, the force versus displacement loops at various magnetic fields was obtained. As shown in Figure 4, before each testing, a preload of 15 N was applied on the MR isolator and set the zero displacement position. The isolator worked in a compression situation.

caption.p: Force versus displacement loops at various magnetic fields.

sec.p: Unlike conventional performances of MRF dampers, where force–displacement loops are symmetrical (Li et al., 2000) the developed MRE isolator has more complex working conditions. In order to support heavy loading, the MRE isolator works at a combination of both shear and compress modes. The elastic force is symmetric, which can be observed at hysteresis loop without magnetic field. But the magnetic force is asymmetric, because the compressed MRE reduces the thickness of MRE layer and the gap between iron particles, and increases the magnetic force. The hysteresis loops under magnetic field are not symmetric any more. In addition, the asymmetric behavior of a MRF damper under the compression working mode has been reported by quite a few research groups. As a matter of fact, if a MRF damper works in the compression mode, its force–displacement loops were also reported as asymmetrical (Wang et al., 1999).
With the measured data, an equivalent linear model through effective elastic stiffness and effective viscous damping was used to predict the force developed in the MRE isolation.

where FMRE is the resultant force provided by the MRE isolator, keﬀ is the effective stiffness, ceff is the effective viscous damping constant,

Figure 5 shows the identified field-dependent equivalent stiffness and damping keff and ceff, respectively. The control force can be determined and used for the MRE seat system control.

According to Figure 5, the stiffness of the MRE isolator at 3 A control current is about as three times as that at zero field. However, the effective damping factor does not have a consistent trend, which varies with the applied magnetic field. Compared with the effective stiffness, the effective damping factor does not have a notable vriation.

sec.title: Model of MRE seat suspension with driver
sec.p: A seat-driver model consisting of the semi-active MRE isolator suspension and human body is shown in Figure 6. The excitation input from the road is transmitted to the cabin floor. For the simplification of the dynamic modeling, it is assumed that there exists only the vertical motion of the vehicle. On the other hand, the proposed MRE seat suspension system consists of the MRE isolator, seat frame, and cushion, as shown in Figure 6. The MRE isolator is modeled with the equivalent stiffness and damping, as shown in equation (1). The cushion and body are modeled by a set of linear springs and dampers whose characteristics are constant. Therefore, the governing equation of the motion of the MRE seat suspension with human body can be obtained as follows

caption.p: Vibration model of the magnetorheological elastomer (MRE) seat suspension system with human body.

sec.title: Controller formulation
sec.p: The control strategy based on nonresonance theory was used to control the isolator (Kobori et al., 1993; Pnevmatikos et al., 2004). Kobori described the seismic structural response process using the asymptotic motion equation (Kobori et al., 1993).

The time-varying transfer function [E(t)] implies the dynamically controllable property in the seismic response control system. This isolator aims to reduce the current response by altering the stiffness in [E(t)], that is, to avert resonance under any excitation. By altering its parameters, the system can avoid the buildup of dominant periodic components of excitation. Thus, the input energy to the system and the system response can be reduced. For seismic control, it can reduce the structure’s displacement response as well as acceleration response, and it is the same requirement with the seat vibration control. Kobori suggested a control algorithm to shift the building frequencies as far away as possible from the disturbance dominant frequencies. The derived optimal result was that the stiffness of system should be increased if the product of drift
x ( t )
and velocity

are opposite to each other, then the stiffness should be decreased. For this simple control algorithm, the long time calculation of feedback signals can be avoided and real-time control can be obtained easily. In this article, the control is designed as
where i(t) is the control signal.

sec.title: Performance evaluation and discussion
sec.p: In order to compare the control effect, parameters similar to those used in the study by Choi and Han (2007) were selected. In this simulation, m1, m2, and m3 are 15, 1, and 70 kg; k2 and k3 are 18,000 and 90,000 N/m; c2 and c3 are 200 and 2064 Ns/m, respectively. ceff can be adjusted to 830 Ns/m and considered as a constant. keff is 31,000 N/m without control and 93,000 N/m with maximum control current.

sec.title: Single sine sweeping waves excitation
sec.p: Figure 7 presents the comparison of theoretical results of MRE isolator in time domain. Figure 7(a) shows the excitation signal, which is a sine sweeping wave with an amplitude of 1 cm from 1 to 20 Hz during a period of 20 s. Figure 7(b) shows the displacement of the body with passive isolator. Figure 7(c) denotes the response of nonresonant controlled system. Because the frequency domain includes the resonance frequency of the system, the response shows a high peak at the frequency. The magnitude at resonance frequency of uncontrolled seat is about 1.8, while the controlled seat decreases the magnitude at same frequency to 1. It means no resonance happened on the controlled seat. It is clear that the amplitude ratio of the nonresonant controlled system is lower than that of the passive system, that is, the controlled MR isolator has a better isolation effect.

caption.p: Theoretical results of the magnetorheological elastomer (MRE) isolator under chirp excitation in time domain. (a) excitation signal; (b) body displacement with a passive isolator; and (c) the response of nonresonant controlled system

sec.title: White noise excitation
sec.p: As shown in Figure 8(a), a white noise excitation was induced to evaluate the isolation effect. Figure 7(b) and (c) show the displacement of the body with passive isolator and MRE isolator, respectively. The root mean square (RMS) of uncontrolled seat is 13.282, and the RMS of controlled seat is 10.159, which shows a reduction of 12.5% compared with the uncontrolled seat. The MRE isolator can reduce the response peak of the body.

caption.p: Theoretical results of the magnetorheological elastomer (MRE) isolator under white noise excitation in time domain. (a) white noise excitation; (b) body displacement with the passive isolator; and (c) body displacement with the MRE isolator.

sec.title: Bump excitation
sec.p: According to the study by Choi and Han (2007), a bump profile is used to reveal the transient response characteristic (as shown in Figure 9(a)). The response of the passive and MRE isolators are shown in Figure 9(b). Comparing the peak values of responses, the controlled seat can reduce about 22% of response compared with the uncontrolled seat. It can be assured that the MRE isolator can reduce the response of the body when compared with the passive system.

caption.p: Theoretical results of the magnetorheological elastomer (MRE) isolator under bump excitation in time domain. (a) bump excitation; and (b) responses with a passive and MRE isolators.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Again, the simulation results were based on the assumption that the effective MRE stiffness is 10-fold of the scaled MRE isolator stiffness. This is reasonable as 10 such small-scaled MRE isolators, which are working in a parallel configuration, would provide the required stiffness used in this simulation. However, the practical application may need a full-scaled MRE isolator to realize the proposed tasks. It is known that the stiffness of a MRE isolator is given by

where G is the MRE shear modulus, A is the shear area, and t is the MRE thickness. Based on the practical requirement, the dimensions of the full-scaled MRE isolator can be determined in principle. For example, a basic process is to simply amplifying to times of the small-scaled MRE isolator size. It is also noted that the practical design and implementation of a full-scaled MRE isolator will still need intensive research tasks, such as optimization, manufacturing, control strategy development, and so on.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This article describes the design, testing, and experimental evaluation of a MRE isolator and simulation analysis of its vibration control effectiveness. Main findings include

list-item.p: Experimental results on MRE material demonstrated that it exhibits notably variable stiffness characteristics

A new MR isolator, where MRE material works in both shear and squeeze modes, was prototyped and its field-dependent stiffness was experimentally studied. The MRE prototype has a three-time stiffness increase when the external coil current varies from 0 to 3 A.

By scally altering the system’s stiffness based on the nature of excitation through an appropriate stiffness control algorithm, the vehicle’s vibration energy input to seat can be reduced to avoid resonance. The isolator’s stiffness is actively controlled to establish a nonresonant state against base excitations, thus suppressing the seat’s response. Results show that the MRE isolator can reduce vibration further than the passive isolation system, indicating the significant potential of its application in vehicle seat vibration control.

ack.p: The author (W.H.L) wishes to thank the Australian Government for awarding an Endeavour Research Fellowship, 1994–2011, to conduct collaboration research with the host, Prof. W.J. Wen, in Hong Kong University of Science & Technology.
